body:
Problem: RSS feeds often have both an image tag and itunes:image tag. In my experience, the "normal" image tag often points nowhere or not to the image we want. The itunes tag is usually right.

Thus, we should prefer the itunes:image tag to the other tags and only use those as a fallback when the itunes tag is not present.

This is a partial solution to #1332, which might not even be a real problem after all.
title: Prefer iTunes image over everything else

body:
Phone: Motorola Moto X 2011
Android Version: 5.1
Kernel version: 3.4.42-g756aa87
AntennaPod version: 1.4.0.2

The home screen widget is a 1-high-by-4-wide widget that lists the podcast's title, includes a track progress time indicator in the form of "current hh:mm:ss / total hh:mm:ss" and a play/pause button.

If the AntennaPod app has not recently been opened, is not listed in the recent apps list, or was at some point exited by the Android OS to clear up RAM, the widget does not fully work. In this situation, you see the most recent track's title and the play button, but no progress/total time. Upon hitting the play button, I do see it's on/off-touch actions as the background highlights, but it does not start playing. 

At this point, I see two options:

Option 1: First open the app (using its main icon or clicking elsewhere on widget) and then hit the play button. Now it's registered, and so when you go back to the widget, you now see the current/total time and the widget's play button will function.

Option 2: First open the app (using its main icon or clicking elsewhere on widget), but then do **not** actually hit the play button. Go back to the widget. If you do this, the play button will now function, but the area of the widget which _should_ show the current/total time is still blank. Once this happens, I can't figure out how to get the current/total time to show on the app again. Play/pause it as much as you want, either from the widget or within the app, it looks like the current/total time will not return to the app until the app is cleared from memory (by Android or by you manually) and you execute the steps listed above in Option 1.

I know this is really corner case stuff. You have no obligation to address my issues, I'm just happy to provide you information.
title: Android home screen widget requires first opening main app

body:

# Current (as per #1241)
![cleanup_settings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5216560/10257690/df66355e-6926-11e5-9ff2-75c2ad425fc3.png)

# Enhencement
A bit more flexibility in these settings could be nice:

**Remove episodes:**
- After: [radio buttons]
 - completing playback [default]
 - pausing(/skipping) or completing playback
- With a delay of: [dropdown]
 - 0 days (immediately)
 - 1 day [default]
 - 3 days 
 - 5 days
 - 7 days
- But exclude: [checkboxes]
 - favourites [default: Y]
 - episodes in the queue [default: Y]

The advantage of adding 'remove after pausing' is that if you loose interest of an episode and tap 'next' halfway through, these episodes can be automatically deleted after a while and won't take up memory space indefinitely.

**What if you just pause and want to listen to an episode later again?**
Because many people just pause an episode with the intention to listen to it again later, this option should not be the default. In practice, this setting I imagine will almost always be applied in combination with a delay of a couple of days; when the episode has not been restarted after those days, there's probably a lack of interest (this would be my use case, with a setting of 5 days).

**inspiration**
Use-case of @charlesay in #1262.
title: More extensive Cleanup settings

body:
Antennapod feature request - "Cog Gears" multiselection for Downloaded Episodes.


---

Hello Antennapodders,

Good work and many thanks! 

Here is a feature request for a workflow:

* Please enable the enhanced "cog gears and filter" multiselect interface, as it exists for the Podcast Episode listing, for the "Completed Downloads" group. (This button appears in the top row of icons)


My particular circumstance (Antennapod 1.3.4.1 dark theme- Samsung S4 mini running AICP custom ROM):

I've downloaded LOTS of episedes while I have a good wifi connection. They all enqueue, which is good, but for so many it's hard to sort them properly. So I actually cleared the queue of 145 episodes and now its quite difficult to rebuild it.

When I go to the Downloads section via the side bar, I find myself on the blank Running slide-tab. Since any particular user is only actually running the downloads for a short period, it might be better to have "Completed" as the initial display.

On the completed slide-tab, I've got the rubbish bin icons on the right to delete individual episodes, but I can't multiselect, filter, group or sort the downloaded episodes. 

If this Completed Downloads interface had the enhanced filtering and multi-select,  we'd be able to 1) rebuild the queue much more efficiently, 2) bulk delete accidentally downloaded, 3) use sort and filter to review the entire collection.



--

This appears to have a similar background to #1209" Add filter and sort options to the "All episodes" view #1209 "

Apologies if this has been requested or phrased in a different thread. I just signed onto Github with Antennapod as the catalyst (hooray!)....and while I think I saw something similar in the issues archive, for the life of me I cannot find the thread!
title: Antennapod feature request - "Cog Gears" + Filters + Sort for Downloaded Episodes.

This idea results from reading through the sleep timer improvements implemented with #1072 :-) Those could IMHO be supported by a function to dynamically reduce the playback speed (if [Prestissimo](https://github.com/TheRealFalcon/Prestissimo) is installed) from whatever the user has set to 1.0. It could work by simply distributing the `Playback Speeds` steps along the `Sleep Timer`'s time axis with the 1st "downstep" happening immediately.

Example: Speeds 1.0, 1.25, 1.5 and 1.75 are set upBefore starting the timer, playback is at 1.5x. Setting the sleep timer to 20min, the first 10min play at 1.25 (immediate downstep) and the last 10 at 1.0. If 1.75x was used before and 30min are then timed, 10min each would play at 1.5, 1.25 and 1.0.
title: dial playback speed down to 1.0 during sleep timer

body:
As to not take over the main discussion in #836 about a special feeds-screen, I'll continue the discussion here about my proposal to move down the 'add podcast' entry in the navigation drawer to below the list of individual feeds, plus the proposal to unpin settings, both in order to free up space higher up in the menu. My reply to the comments by @Cathryne:
> Do I understand correctly, that these suggestions would make the "distance-to-option" dependent on the number of subscribed podcasts?

Yes

> If yes, why punish listeners with many subscriptions in this way?

Well, I guess that's one way to look at it ^^ Instead of focussing on a negative attitude of developers/the programme ('punishing the listeners'), I would like to look at the likelyhood of an option being used. I don't know about you, but personally, and I would think many users with me, tap on a feed in the drawer far more often than they tap on 'Add podcast'. If this is indeed is the case for most users, then to me it only makes sense to put the 'add podcast' entry below the feed list in the drawer. The less often a function gets used, the higher its' "distance-to-option" can be (and vice versa). Plus, the larger the list of 

> It's IMHO fine to have a few items pinned (configurable & rather at the top, than at the bottom, but hey!).

Sure, it's absolutely fine to have a few items pinned. But, again, following the reasoning above, the "distance-to-option" relative to how often a function is used, would make it only logical to not have the settings pinned. Indeed this is in line with (current) [Material Design guide](http://www.google.be/design/spec/patterns/navigation-drawer.html#navigation-drawer-content).
And pinning items at the top I feel really goes against all UI/UX conventions :P

> In order to clean up space the vertical space of each item & podcast title should be reduced. The necessity to shrink the covers in the drawer to about half their current size would IMHO be balanced out by aa separate subscription view with large cover images (not sure I'd use it, because I really like the drawer list).

Although I see that the vertical height of the menu items, the feeds could be reduced, I absolutely wouldn't shrink the feed images any further; on [my phone](https://fairphone.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/201064718-What-are-the-technical-specifications-of-the-Fairphone-1-)'s 4.3 inch screen, I'm already *just able* to see the images properly (as in: being able to see what's on an image, with [No Agenda](http://feed.nashownotes.com/rss.xml) being the worst).
As you say, people would still use the nav drawer to navigate between feeds quickly, and most of us would only use the subscriptions view only for a more 'immersive' view (plus reaching archived feeds that may be added in future as per #1182). As the subscription view is 'extra' (at least it seems to be for the both of us), for me shrinking images doesn't balance out as you say.
title: Freeing up space in the nav drawer

body:
Go to the menu, select "Downloads".  Then swipe to the "Completed" tab.  The size of the downloaded podcast is shown next to the lower right corner of the podcast icon.  Usually this is a plausible value.  For example: "21 MB".  Occasionally it displays "0 B".  The download will still play, so this is not a failed download.  

This happens on AntennaPod 1.3.3.0.  It occurs on both phones I use for podcasts:
  *  Moto G (XT1031) with Android 4.4.4. 
  *  Kyocera Hydro Vibe (C6725) with Android 4.4.2

Some podcasts seem more likely to have this problem.  But it does not happen consistently.  "On The Media", "This American Life", and "Planet Money" seem to have  it occur most frequently.

This is a really minor issue.  The strange download size is just a little confusing as it might indicate a problem with the download.
title: Completed Downloads page occasionally indicates "0 B" as download size

I'm afraid this is going to be a hard to reproduce bug as it only does this to me maybe one in fifty times, but it's sufficiently annoying and it happens regularly enough to seem worth reporting.

I haven't spotted specific patterns that trigger it but I think it only happens when I'm using my bluetooth headphones, and when I use the play button on them to resume playback. What I expect to happen is that the podcast episode I'm half-way through starts, what actually happens is the episode gets marked as played and deleted (I don't have it configured to keep files otherwise I run out of space). Sometimes it'll also delete the next couple of episodes I have queued as well.

This is infuriating if I'm out as I can't re-download the ~150mb file even over 3g as it's just not reliable enough so I don't get to listen to what I had queued until I'm home again. It's also minorly annoying because I have to find my place in the episode again when I've re-downloaded it.

Love the app, and it keeps getting better with every update.

version info:

* Google Nexus 4
* CyanogenMod 12-20150322-NIGHTLY-mako / Android 5.0.2 (shh don't tell anyone I don't like updates, people keep breaking things)
* f-droid
* antennapod 1.3.1 (2f55256)

Usually listening to NoAgenda (in the morning!) http://feed.nashownotes.com/rss.xml but that could be coincidence as that's most of my listening material.

Sorry I haven't been able to pin this down further.
title: Occasionally unexpectedly skips entire episode(s)

body:
I have AntennaPod on my Fairphone 1 (Android 4.2.2). There seems to be something weird with the changelog related to language. Data shown in the 'What's new' section on Google Play varries in different situations.

* In the Google Play store on my phone:
 * if phone settings Language = Dutch -> data for version 1.2
 * if phone settings Language = English -> data for version 1.3.2
* On Google Play online (web):
 * if not logged in (interface language = Dutch) -> data for version 1.3.2
 * if logged in (preferred language for Google products = Dutch) -> data for version 1.2
 * if logged in (preferred language for Google products = Dutch) -> data for version 1.3.2

I'm wondering: is this an issue with (bug in) Google Play, or a matter of [updating the 'What's new'](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/189724) on Google for different languages?
title: Google Play store version info language dependent(?)

Currently, the feed info and settings are combined in one screen in the feed overview. Maybe it's an idea to make the whole 'cover area' (image, background, title & producer) clickable, leading to a screen with the info (author, language, URL, description, button to open podcast website); and replace the 'i' icon with cogwheels, leading to a screen where settings specifict to that feed can be applied (include in auto-download, auto delete episodes, authentication).

Visually it would be nice if the 'cover area' would be kept, the buttons in the top right removed, the global menu replaced with a 'back' arrow, the additional info/settings would replace the episodes overview. [list of proposed screens and changes in comment below]

- The cogwheels are now grey, as if the option is not available, and should be white (like the buttons on both its sides)

title: 'Apply actions' improvement suggestion

body:
I accidentally bulk added all episodes of one feed to the queue via the 'Apply actions' screen. Now I'm stuck with 145 episodes - that I already have listened to - in my queue. Would be nice to also be able to undo this via the bulk edit, rather than via individual edits from the queue screen.

This would mean yet another option in the bottom bar, and so I would propose to change the menu to some kind of 'pull up' (rather than 'drop down') menu at the bottom where the preferred action can be selected, plus an 'apply action' button on the right side of it.
This would also give more space to the descriptions of the different functions (the Dutch ones take more space than the English ones).

(I guess another option would be to add 'Bulk manage episodes' from the contextual menu in the Queue screen, but to me that wouldn't be as logical.)
title: FR: Bulk Remove from queue

body:
Hello,
Today I did not use my Phone and the battery went from 80% to 10% in a few hours.
A look in Wakelock Detector told me that my Phone was active all the time. AntennaPod (more exactly: com.aocate.media.ServiceBackedMediaPlayer) prevented the CPU from sleeping for 93% of the up time (since 1d and a few hours)!
During this period I was in flight mode, did not listen to any episode and nothing was paused, either. So AntennaPod should have been (almost) completely inactive.

After I forced AntennaPod to exit the battery stayed at 10% for 3 hours :)

I use CyanogenMod 12.1 and AntennaPod 1.3.1.
title: Battery: Persistent CPU wakelocks when inactive

body: The time displayed at the top of the queue is the summed time of the total length of all podcasts in the queue. This seems a less useful number than the summed time of all the time left in each podcast, at least for indicating how much time listening to the queued podcasts will add up to.
title: Time total in queue should show summed time remaining, not total time

body:
Taking the feature request by @Threore in the issue on enhancements for AP v 1.3:

"I do a lot of my podcast listening while riding to university on a bicycle, which means wind and traffic often make it hard to hear the podcasts. The obvious solution is to turn the volume up, but some podcasts are so much louder than others that going from one to the other becomes jarring. Some setting or automatic feature that normalises all the audio would be great."

Same for me; sometimes I'll just pull out my headphones on the bike when I can't hear what they're talking about on a new episode from the queue (no, I don't have buttons on my earplugs to skip episode or adjust volume :) )

I would like to add the option to set audio levels to the softer, middle or louder podcasts (I know this boils down to an additional volume setting front-end, but back-end it would be determining the volume edit between finishing normalisation and saving the file). Reason: normalisation may not be enough to pump up the volume high enough to suit biking (although maybe I'm wring here).
title: Audio-normalisation (& volume correction)

body:
Hi,

I have several podcasts and sometimes they do not get downloaded properly. But the error line on the Downloads/Log view can neither be expanded nor provides enough information to actually understand what's happening.

I propose a new feature -- say when pressing or long pressing on a line -- that would show a full URL (so I can copy/paste it in the browser and try it out myself) and show the full error to understand what's going on and if the podcast is even worth following.

See attached screenshot, for example:
- "Unsupported Feed type: Invalid type" tells me nothing
- The URISyntaxException does not tell me what's wrong with the URI because I cannot see it.

![Log file](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4567693/9243872/e3f56c6a-4195-11e5-8154-cce38b693d94.png)

body: I don't think this is an intentional feature?  I've seen it happen a number of times (Alpha version), possibly just when trying to skip back more than one jump in quick succession.

body:
Auto download always downloads newest episodes first. So, if the episode cache size is smaller than the number of unplayed items, older episodes are never downloaded.
Another problem is that if there are multiple new episodes from the same feed, the newer episodes end up at the top of the queue, while the other way around would make more sense.
Of course I can manually reorder the queue, but it would be nice if the order of new episodes was retained automatically.
title: Option to auto download oldest episodes first

body:
It's possible to have non-downloaded items in the queue. The summary at the top of the queue includes the duration of podcasts that haven't been downloaded yet.

Is this a good idea?  Should we only include downloaded podcasts?  Should we have an indicator that they're not all downloaded?

As I recall the desired use case was someone who is about to go on a trip and wants to make sure they have enough for the road.
title: Queue duration summary includes non-downloaded episodes in count

body:
1. When you are in the view "New episodes" you can do a swipe to the right to remove an entry (mark as played), but a swipe to the left does nothing. It would be great if you could use a swipe to the left for putting an entry into the queue (without downloading).

2. It would be great if you could configure each podcast feed individually to NOT be displayed in the "New episodes" view. I have a few podcast feeds with 10 or more new entries per day, but I rarely download any of them. They just needlessly fill up my "New episode" view. When I really want to see them I can open the specific feed I need.

3. A sorting mechanism for "Queue" which separates already downloaded entries from not downloaded entries.
title: 3 feature requests

We send the GpodnetEpisodeAction PLAY when items are marked as read. At least we do in some when the user users the menu item to mark something as 'Played'.

However, we don't always send this action when an item is marked as read.  For example: when a user swipes an episode away in 'New Episodes' or when they 'Mark all as played'.  Since this can happen in so many places we might want to centralize these actions.  Either doing so in DBWriter or some other helper class.

Thinking this is low priority.
title: GpodnetEpisodeAction not sent for all 'PLAY' actions

body:
The course of events is somewhat complicated, so here is everything in chronological order:

My phone is an LG Optimus G (e975), running Cyanogenmod. This device has no sd card slot, external storage is emulated at ```/storage/emulated/0```.
1. It was running Cyanogenmod 11 (Android 4.4 iirc) and AntennaPod 1.1.2. I didn't encounter any of the issues below then.
2. As CM 12 became available I upgraded to that version, upgrading the Google Apps in the process.
3. Soon later I noticed AntennaPod wasn't updating feeds properly, a new episode wasn't shown even after manual refresh, though it was clearly in the feed. Using paged feeds also didn't work, the "v" button was shown, but pressing it yielded no results after loading was done.
4. I noticed AntennaPod's version on F-Droid (1.1.2) was outdated, so I reinstalled 1.2 from Google Play. Starting AntennaPod results in the error: ```No external storage is available . Please make sure that external storage is mounted so that the app can work proplerly.```
5. Rebooting, removing cache and data, reinstalling, disabling PrivacyGuard didn't fix it.
6. Best part: Reinstalling 1.1.2 from F-Droid now also yields the “No external storage is available” message.

Despite all this, it's nice to see the latest progress!
title: "No external storage is available" on Cyanogenmod 12 / Lollipop (LG Optimus G)

body:
I would welcome a feature to stream podcasts to dlna/upnp media renderers (cf. #280). I have implemented a proof of concept for such afeature using the cling library. (Personally, I don't consume any video podcasts and I didn't not care about them in my current implementation.) It took me a while from the first attempt, so my implementation is based on a somewhat outdated version of AntennaPod. I encourage you to have a look at it: https://github.com/volhol/AntennaPod/tree/streammedia

On the MediaplayerActivity you can find a new Item in the menu called select media renderer. 

![menu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11587858/8340733/92a87240-1ac0-11e5-9dad-64fe018aba4a.PNG)

The app tries to find all suitable medai renderers in your local network. Just select one. The app then attemps to play the current media item form the current position on the chosen media renderer.

![select media renderer](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11587858/8340740/9c055b14-1ac0-11e5-96f0-ee32210acc74.PNG)

In fact, the app does currently not stream the content to the device itself. Instead it transmits the original URL to the device and asks it to stream the content from there. It may take a while before you can start playback. During this time, you see that the play/pause button changes appearance. Sometimes you may have to press the play button two to three time before the playback starts. Once the media item is played back on the media renderer, you can change the current position as well as the volume like you would in local mode. (Altering the volume works from the MediaplayerActivity only.)  The fast torward/reqind button disapppear since there is no suitable feature for this in dlna/upnp.

I have tested this feature on the four dlna/upnp media renderers I have access to. I found out that each of them behaves a bit differently. Thus, it may not work properly on your devices.

I am of course open to any discussion on if and how this feature could be integrated with an AntennaPod release (standard feature, separate module as prestissimo, ...). I tried to isolate most changes in separate files. Please be aware that the cling library (http://4thline.org/projects/cling/) requires at least API 15.
title: Streaming to dlna/upnp devices (proof of concept available)

body:
Hi

Maybe it makes sense to not to add a podcast, but the thing is there could be temporary connection issues with the podcast providers. 

Here is a scenario. I have 60 podcasts in an opml file. I import it and some of them fail during import and APod does not add them. They are not listed. Well what if the connection issue is temporary from the server? Sometimes the providers might get hit with lots of request which disables their response?

I think that it will make more sense if APod adds the all the podcasts during import but show some icon or gray it out next to the listing (not in downloads window) to show that it failed during the import. And maybe it will come back during another refresh.

It is a bit confusing this way because hard to keep track of which ones made it back whioch ones are not.
title: APod does not add the podast if the connection fails.

body:
While exploring the antennapod/files/media folder using ES File Explorer, I noticed some episodes that appeared to be still there which I had listened to and according to AP weren't there anymore.
I checked the release dates of those episodes and the 'last modified' date in the properties of these files, and the last modified date is probably the date of when I listened to it.
The file size displayed in the properties was also really small, and when trying to play the files it only plays for a little while before stopping.

What I think is going on is that when AP deletes a finished episode, it sometimes is interrupted somehow and part of the file remains. AP randomly crashes sometimes, so maybe that's when it gets interrupted? I have no idea how to replicate this but maybe keeping a list of files to be deleted and checking afterwards if they indeed are would work.

Edit: The files and dates, though I'm pretty sure it's nothing specific about these files or dates.

body:
Now that 1.2 is released it's time to start thinking about 1.3.

There have been some suggestions for major UI improvements. Some visible, some under the covers.  I think it would make sense to think through all the GUI related features and changes we want and try to make them all work well together.

Some thoughts on improvements:
* Material design overhaul
* Use of RecyclerView in place of DSLV
* New subscription view (#848, #836)
* ~~Better sharing of episodes (#861)~~
* Display of itunes 'explicit' tags (#724)
* Filtering by itunes 'explicit' tags (#725)
* ~~Support for multiple queues~~
 * I don't think this will happen in 1.3
* ~~Improve visibility of adding podcasts via iTunes~~ - Done
 * This is really the easiest way of adding podcasts
 * Perhaps making it the first option users see and only labeling it 'search'?
* ~~Download all episodes from a feed (#871, #520)~~
* Episode forward/back (#732)

I bet there are some other good thoughts on what could be done. 

We should think hard about any changes to how we interact with the app, how these features would change them and how they could all work together.
title: Any ideas for AntennaPod 1.3?

body:
The way I use AntennaPod (or any podcast player) makes it important how episodes are deleted. My favorite way to limit space taken up by media is to be able to set a time limit on storing episodes: Do not keep any episode longer than 7, 14, 30 or 60 days for example. There's other fancier way of doing this but it would move AntennaPod towards settings bloat. 

The way it's done in AntennaPod is a bit confusing for me. I know that episodes are deleted when played becuase I have set them to, but what if I swipe the episode off the queue while playing because I'm not interested and move to the next episode? When will that episode be deleted? Also, is it possible that AntennaPod "forgets" episodes somehow and never delete them, or will all episodes above the set number be deleted? What happens if I add an episode to the media directory manually. Will AntennaPod ever notice that file and delete it? I am just trying to understand how it works since I seem to end up with more media stored than set for the cache limit (i use 40). Finally, an option to have any episode not in the queue deleted would be helpful.

I would not have to ask any of these questions if AntennaPod had the option to time limit storage like for instance (the bloated) BeyondPod has, so I think I would like to add such an option as a feature request.
title: More questions (and suggestions) about the cache.

body:
In the [UI discussion](https://github.com/danieloeh/AntennaPod/issues/407#issuecomment-41489319) leading up to release [0.9.9](https://github.com/danieloeh/AntennaPod/releases/tag/0.9.9.0) I pointed out some areas of space saving possibilities. Some of those were implement then or during the last few months and IMHO improved the usefulness of AntennaPod a lot.

I had hoped for another round of (esp. vertical) screen real estate savings in [0.9.9.5](https://github.com/danieloeh/AntennaPod/releases/tag/0.9.9.5), but alas: no. My perception is that larger and higher-res screens will spread, but for those who are for whatever reason stuck with smaller Android devices like the [Galaxy S2 (480x800px)](http://www.samsung.com/de/consumer/mobile-device/mobilephones/archive-mobile-phones/GT-I9100LKADBT-spec), please add a(n option for) compact mode.

Suggestions on where space can be shaved off individual items in any of the list views so that more items may be visible on the screen:
- move publishing dates and file sizes or play times respectively above and below the download or symbols
- shrink images to the height of 2 lines of main text (favicons in the browser are already much smaller and still server their recognition purpose; also, AntennaPod already has zoomed views for podcast and episode images in their respective views)
- extend playtime indicator line to left and right (matching play time on right below play symbol) so that it can act as a separator between episodes

body:
Hello!

I'd like to collect some pros and cons about the default update interval & suggest an "automatic" option.

In my experience (heavy podcast listener, always a screen full for episodes in play-list), all podcatchers that do have a default interval, have a very short one. This causes unnecessary data usage & CPU load, also for the hosters. I'm in a podcast team myself and saw the logs. Many users (same IP & client) appear with hour intervals...

So, I usually activate the maximum pre-configured update interval. In AntennaPod this is 24h. Since there is probably no 1-interval-(range-)fits-all here, how about some kind of adaptive/automatic/dynamic setting? As default, not as yet another option ;-)

For example:

1. Take the existing intervals, but make them mean "remaining playtime in queue), so that in my example, an auto-refresh would be triggered if the playtime drops below 24h (still respecting the "Mobile update"-setting & WiFi filter).
2. Or, make the interval adjust itself to half, third, quarter (Let's discuss what's sensible here!) of queue playtime. Current, or averaged over a sensible time.
3. update feeds individually, when playback of last remaining episode in it starts

Please let me & us know what you think about this.
title: automatic adjustment of update interval

body:
I have a few ideas for refactorings I’d like to run by the project. When I implemented OPML backup I saw some places where I think it would be beneficial for the app to “offload” functionality to other libraries and services. Less code (and sources of bugs) at the expense (possibly) of less control. Specifically,
 
1. EventDistributor can be replaced (or backed) with [LocalBroadcastManager](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v4/content/LocalBroadcastManager.html) that ships with the support libaries

   This is a small change and would be straight forward to implement. The EventDistributor API could stay the same.

1. Use [Volley](https://android.googlesource.com/platform/frameworks/volley/) (or other library designed to download small files) to download feeds and images (it also does caching)

1. Use the [Download Manager](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/DownloadManager.html) to download podcasts and videos
 
   Getting HTTP downloads right is not straight forward (AntennaPod has 8 classes for this purpose) and requires threads, locks, background services and notifications to work properly. Download Manager takes care of all that and does retries as well as handles connectivity failures. It is not clear that using Download Manager would work exactly the same as the current solution, but I think it will and I’m willing to give it a shot.
 
I appreciate all the time and effort that was put in to these parts of the app, and would totally understand if there's hesitation in changing them too much. The obvious reason not to is that it currently works. Also, these changes would not change how AntennaPod functions or looks. If, however, you think it’d be a good idea to simplify the code base then I would be interested in seeing if we can make it work. What do you think?
title: Ideas for code refactorings

If activated, a reasonable amount (maybe 50% of set episode cache size?) of old episodes from that feed get treated as new & therefore automatically downloaded. In chronological order starting with the oldest one. Here, [Podlove Paged Feeds](http://podlove.org/paged-feeds/) should be taken into account.

Another, IMHO less important use-case is wanting to listen to random old episodes from a podcast, or even from all subscribed podcasts. If the above feature idea of archive downloading is accepted, it would hopefully not be a big deal to also add a "random archive download"-option, either to the show information screen of a podcast, or as a general setting.

In any case, the latest episode in a newly added feed should be treated as new, so that it get's shuffled into the waiting list or queue like any truly new episode.

body:
The Atom specification permits multiple files - one possible use for this is to do away with separate feeds for each podcast media format and include all available formats in a single feed.

In this case, AntennaPod appears to simply download whatever format (that is recognized) is last in the list. I created a test "feed" (valid single-entry atom xml file) with the media enclosures in the same format order I use for HTML5 audio <source> tags (i.e. preferred first). When the legacy mp3 format is last in the list, AntennaPod downloads the mp3 (skipping over the Ogg Vorbis version and the two other formats that it presumably doesn't recognize [opus and speex]). If I move the Ogg Vorbis version to the end of the list, the .ogg file is downloaded instead.

Short term: I would have expected it to instead default to the FIRST one (on the assumption that the "preferred" formats would be put first in the feed by the feed author, the same way users of the <audio> HTML5 tag do).

Long term (feature request): some sort of selection interface allowing download of any or all enclosures in at Atom entry (in addition to different formats of the same podcast media, multiple enclosures might also include "supporting media" such as diagram images, "show notes" text or pdf files, audio in different spoken languages, etc.)

The static single-entry Atom "feed" that I'm using for testing currently may be found here: http://blinky.dogphilosophy.net/atomtest.xml
title: Atom feeds with multiple enclosures: wrong(?). file downloaded

body:
This issue is related to #135. A small reordering of the Network settings could make them clearer and avoid unwanted 3G usage. I think the Network settings should be as follows:

AUTOMATIC UPDATE

- Both on WiFi and 3G.
- Only on WiFi.
- Never update automatically (selected by default).

UPDATE INTERVAL (greyed out if automatic update is enabled)

- 1 hour / 2 hours / 4 hours / 8 hours / 12 hours / 24 hours.

AUTOMATIC DOWNLOADING OF ENQUEUED EPISODES

- Both on WiFi and 3G.
- Only on WiFi (selected by default).
- Never download enqueued episodes automatically.

AUTOMATIC STREAMING OF ENQUEUED EPISODES

- Checkbox: stream on 3G if it's their turn to play (unchecked by default).

EPISODE CACHE

- 10 episodes / 20 episodes / 40 episodes / 60 episodes / 80 episodes / 100 episodes.

WiFi FILTER

- Checkbox: treat unselected networks as if they were 3G.
- Checkboxes: list of known networks.

There are several advantages to this:

Data usage can be set more easily because you can set what the app can or cannot do while on 3G (and on WiFi) in a single field, without the need for an extra checkbox (as opposed to the "mobile updates" checkbox in the current version).

All related options are together, and unrelated ones are separate: the automatic update setting is next to the update interval, but far from the WiFi filter (because the latter affects several other things).

Last but not least, the "Automatic streaming of enqueued episodes" checkbox allows us to have a single action instead of the highly overlapping "Download" and "Enqueue", which is covered in #135.
title: Reorder the Network settings

body:
This issue is related to #116 because it implies the workflow suggested there.

When you long-press an episode you get a lot of options that could be simplified:

![Screenshot_2013-03-07-16-50-09](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/232777/7ef0850a-8740-11e2-9aaf-15b31a01ae58.png)

In that screenshot:

- "Remove" deletes the file but leaves the episode in the playing queue.
- "Remove from queue" returns the file to the waiting list, but keeps the file in the phone.

If #116 is implemented neither of the above would make sense because being in the queue imply being downloaded, and the other way around. But we do need:

- A "Remove" option that completely deletes the file and makes the app forget about the episode. This should apply to items in the queue, waiting list or history. Also, in addition to a long-press action this could be triggered by swiping the episode away.
- An "Add to queue" option that takes items from the waiting list or the history and adds them to the bottom of the playing queue. Also, of course, sets them to be downloaded ASAP.
- Optionally some "Return to waiting list" and "Move to history" options for items in the queue. I don't think I would want these, though: once you move an episode to the queue you probably won't want to move it back unless you've lost your interest and don't want to listen to it anymore, in which case it would be simpler to just swipe it away and be done with it.

- "Mark as read" removes the "new" banner.
- "Mark as unread" adds it again.

I find these largely irrelevant and, unless I've misunderstood their function, I don't think they're worth two slots in the long-press menu.

Therefore, if you long-press an item in the playing queue I think that you should get these options:

- Play, which moves the episode to the top and starts playing it.
- Remove, already explained.

And if you long-press an item in the waiting list or history you should get:

- Play.
- Remove.
- Add to playing queue, which adds it to the bottom of the queue.

In addition to that, It could be useful to show these options as buttons on the bottom bar so that you can apply them to several items at once. Here's a quick mockup:

![Antennapod](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/233013/00638e92-8747-11e2-8fd0-dd6cf3057409.png)

As you see the mockup shows several selected items and three buttons at the bottom bar, which correspond to Play, Remove and Add to queue.
title: Simplify the long-press menu

body:
This suggestion is related to #79 and #116 because it uses a single queue and doesn't distinguish between new and old episodes, but downloaded and undownloaded.

I think that switching to a card interface would make the queue look cleaner and make it easier to delete unwanted episodes:

![Antennapod](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/226933/111fa5a4-8648-11e2-97a1-1d5f7791bdfa.png)

As you see, each episode is separated from the rest and all the relevant data appears in a clean way: you can see the episode's title and channel, as well as duration and progress (except for undownloaded episodes, which show their size instead).

Similarly to #79, the episode being played is shown at the top of the queue. Its card is a bit bigger than the rest and shows some extra data. It also has a bigger proggress bar that lets you scroll through the episode.

As specified in #116 all new episodes are added to the bottom of the "Undownloaded" list. As you listen to the ones at the top they get deleted, making room, and the ones at the top of "Undownloaded" are downloaded and moved to the bottom of the "Downloaded" list, so that you know that you can listen to them without using any mobile data.

You can browse through the whole list and if any particular episodes don't attract you you can simply swipe them away and make room for new ones, which is one of the main benefits of the card interface.

If you're browsing through the Undownloaded episodes and you see one that you like you can long-press it and choose to "Play" it (which moves it to the top of the Downloaded list and starts playing it right away) or "Download" it (which moves it to the bottom of the Downloaded list).
title: Try a card interface

title: Add a button for sleep timer in player view
